prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: 12CO (1-0) lines of our proposed targets are located in Band 3. A typical CO line width of BCG is ~300 km/s (Salome & Combes (2003)). In addition, 170 km/s line width of inflow/outflow in A1664 have been found by Russell et al. (2014). In order to probe the small-velocity-scale flow as well as the systematic motion of molecular gas in BCGs, we aim to have at least 5 independent channels over ~100 km/s linewidth. Considering the sensitivity required to achieve our goal, the channel separation of 20 km/s will be a good compromise. In order to find dynamic inflow/outflow of CO gas, we propose to use the correlator mode having the most wide spectral window (~5000 km/s). Since it still provides an enough spectral window resolution, we set the spectral averaging of 8 for saving the data rate while keeping our desired velocity resolution.

Based on previous case studies using ALMA cycle 0, 12CO (1-0) are distributed within 10 kpc-scale (McNarama et al. 2014; Russell et al. 2014). In order to achieve the sensitivity required for this science, 9 synthesized beam components are also required for the farthest case (z=0.055). For imaging the overall morphology of 12CO (1-0), the most compact 12-meter array will be enough to image without flux loss, covering the largest angular size of CO molecules (~ 22.4 arcsec).

Brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) contain molecular gas (>10^9 solar mass) and in some cases approaching 10^11 solar mass (Russell et al. 2014). Since 12CO (1-0) emission of our proposed targets have never been detected, we estimate the expected CO intensity assuming the mass of molecular gas is 10^9 solar mass as a low limit of typical value (use equation 3 in Bolatto et al. 2013 for a review; Xco=0.4e20 from Downes & Solomon 1998 for active galaxy). Our targets are located at various redshift (z=0.022 to 0.055). Considering the farthest object as the dimmest case, the expected peak flux density per synthesized beam (= 3"; see the imaging part of TJ) of 12CO (1-0) line is 2.86 mJy. With a channel of of 20 km/s width (see the correlator configuration part in TJ), we should be able to image in 12CO (1-0) with S/N > 4 ~ 4.4 for all targets.

Since it still provides an enough spectral window resolution, we set the spectral averaging of 8 for saving the data rate while keeping our desired velocity resolution.

Brightest cluster galaxies (BCGs) contain molecular gas (>10^9 solar mass) and in some cases approaching 10^11 solar mass (Russell et al. 2014). Since 12CO (1-0) emission of our proposed targets have never been detected, we estimate the expected CO intensity assuming the mass of molecular gas is 10^9 solar mass as a low limit of typical value (use equation 3 in Bolatto et al. 2013 for a review; Xco=0.4e20 from Downes & Solomon 1998 for active galaxy). Our targets are located at various redshift (z=0.022 to 0.055). Considering the farthest object as the dimmest case, the expected peak flux density per synthesized beam (= 3"; see the imaging part of TJ) of 12CO (1-0) line is 2.86 mJy. With a channel of of 20 km/s width (see the correlator configuration part in TJ), we should be able to image in 12CO (1-0) with S/N > 4 ~ 4.4 for all targets.

12CO (3-2) lines of our proposed targets are located in Band 7. A typical CO line width of BCG is ~300 km/s suggested by Salome & Combes (2003). Also, 190 km/s line width of inflow/outflow in A1664 is reported by Russell et al. (2014). In order to probe the small-velocity-scale flow as well as the systematic motion of molecular gas in BCGs, we aim to have at least 5 independent channels across ~100 km/s. Considering the sensitivity required to achieve our goal, the channel separation of 20 km/s will be a good compromise. In order to find dynamic inflow/outflow motion of CO gas, we propose to use the most wide spectral window (~1700 km/s). It still provide an enough spectral window resolution, so we set the spectral averaging of 16, which is the largest averaging factor in OT, for saving the data rate while keeping our desired velocity resolution.

From case studies using ALMA cycle 0, 12CO (3-2) molecules are distributed within 7 kpc-scale (McNarama et al. 2014; Russell et al. 2014). Considering the redshift of our proposed targets, the largest angular scales are ranging from 10.3" to 15.8". These sizes are larger than maximum recoverable region of the most compact array (see below justification). In order to achieve sensitive imaging, at least 9 synthesized beam are required for the farthest case (z=0.055). Therefore, the 2 synthesized beam from the most compact 12-meter array is good to achieve our goal.

Based on the expected 12CO (1-0) emission in BCGs, we calculate the expected 12CO (3-2) flux using the published CO (3-2)/(1-0) ratio by Papadopoulos et al. (2011) for active galaxies. In this proposal, our targets are distributed in z=0.022 to 0.055. Considering the farthest object as the dimmest case, the expected peak flux density per synthesized beam (= 2?; see the imaging part of TJ) of 12CO (3-2) line is 6.95 mJy. With a proposed velocity resolution of 20 km/s width described in the correlator configuration part in TJ, we should be able to image in 12CO (3-2) with S/N > 4 ~ 4.4 for all targets. Also, dust continuum can be calculated from gas mass and temperature (use the equation 9 in Downes & Solomon et al. 1998; T=30K for active galaxies). The estimated peak continuum flux densities per synthesized beam is ranging from 0.58 to 0.75 mJy. It achieve the S/N > 6.3 ~ 8.1.

Although the expected CO extent is larger than the recoverable scale of the most-compact 12m-array, we are interested in the kinematics of the central molecular region. Therefore, the complementary of ACA observation is not needed for our science.

Also, 190 km/s line width of inflow/outflow in A1664 is reported by Russell et al. (2014). In order to probe the small-velocity-scale flow as well as the systematic motion of molecular gas in BCGs, we aim to have at least 5 independent channels across ~100 km/s. Considering the sensitivity required to achieve our goal, the channel separation of 20 km/s will be a good compromise. It still provide an enough spectral window resolution, so we set the spectral averaging of 16, which is the largest averaging factor in OT, for saving the data rate while keeping our desired velocity resolution.

From case studies using ALMA cycle 0, 12CO (3-2) molecules are distributed within 7 kpc-scale (McNarama et al. 2014; Russell et al. 2014). Considering the redshift of our proposed targets, the largest angular scales are ranging from 10.3? to 15.8?. These sizes are larger than maximum recoverable region of the most compact array (see below justification). Therefore, the 2? synthesized beam from the most compact 12-meter array is good to achieve our goal.

With a proposed velocity resolution of 20 km/s width described in the correlator configuration part in TJ, we should be able to image in 12CO (3-2) with S/N > 4 ~ 4.4 for all targets. Also, dust continuum can be calculated from gas mass and temperature (use the equation 9 in Downes & Solomon et al. 1998; T=30K for active galaxies). Although the expected CO extent is larger than the recoverable scale of the most-compact 12m-array, we are interested in the kinematics of the central molecular region. Therefore, the complementary of ACA observation is not needed for our science.

12CO (3-2) lines of our proposed targets are located in Band 7. A typical CO line width of BCG is ~300 km/s suggested by Salome & Combes (2003). Also, 190 km/s line width of inflow/outflow in A1664 is reported by Russell et al. (2014). In order to probe the small-velocity-scale flow as well as the systematic motion of molecular gas in BCGs, we aim to have at least 5 independent channels across ~100 km/s. Considering the sensitivity required to achieve our goal, the channel separation of 20 km/s will be a good compromise. In order to find dynamic inflow/outflow motion of CO gas, we propose to use the most wide spectral window (~1700 km/s). It still provide an enough spectral window resolution, so we set the spectral averaging of 16, which is the largest averaging factor in OT, for saving the data rate while keeping our desired velocity resolution.

From case studies using ALMA cycle 0, 12CO (3-2) molecules are distributed within 7 kpc-scale (McNarama et al. 2014; Russell et al. 2014). For detecting the overall distribution of 13CO (3-2) in this case, the recoverable region of 6.5? is required. In order to achieve sensitive imaging, also, at least 9 synthesized beams are necessary. Therefore, the 2? synthesized beam from the most compact 12-meter array, which cover maximum ~28? region without flux loss, is the best to achieve our goal.

Based on the expected 12CO (1-0) emission in BCGs, we calculate the expected 12CO (3-2) flux using the published CO (3-2)/(1-0) ratio by Papadopoulos et al. (2011) for active galaxies. In this proposal, our targets are distributed in z=0.022 to 0.055. Considering the farthest object as the dimmest case, the expected peak flux density per synthesized beam (= 2; see the imaging part of TJ) of 12CO (3-2) line is 6.95 mJy. With a proposed velocity resolution of 20 km/s width described in the correlator configuration part in TJ, we should be able to image in 12CO (3-2) with S/N > 4 ~ 4.4 for all targets. Also, dust continuum can be calculated from gas mass and temperature (use the equation 9 in Downes & Solomon et al. 1998; T=30K for active galaxies). The estimated peak continuum flux densities per synthesized beam is ranging from 0.58 to 0.75 mJy. It achieve the S/N > 6.3 ~ 8.1.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose CO (1-0) and CO (3-2) studies of five central galaxies in cool-core and non cool-core clusters. The primary goal is to investigate how the cooling flow relates to the AGN activity of a central cluster galaxy. The CO presence has been suggested to be associated with the cooling flow existence in bright central galaxies. The cooling flow plays a significant role in the evolution of the central cluster galaxies, since its mechanism can launch the formation of cold molecular gas and dust. In consequence, it may affect nuclear activities like AGN and nuclear star formation. On the other hand, it has been suggested that the presence of AGNs may prevent further cooling of gas in the cluster core. Thus an AGN and a cooling flow in the cluster core may affect each others evolution while exchanging feedback. In order to probe the co-evolution of AGNs and cooling flows, we ask for 6.78 hours of ALMA 12-m array observing time.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Michigan State University
Advanced Astronomy and Space Science Division, Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute
Radio Astronomy Division, Korea Astronomy and Space Science Institute
